Badly beaten in their season
opener by fast-moving Franklin
and Marshall, 13-47, Johns Hopkins' gridders tomorrow play host
to Carnegie Tech in an attempt to
gain revenge for last year's 6-40
defeat to the Tartans.

The first' Student Council sponsored assembly of the year will be
held next Friday, October 16, at
10 a.m. It will feature a four-man
discussion panel, entitled "Origin
Of Religion and Its Place Today,"
Charles Peinado, SC assembly
Chairman announced.

Carnegie, bulwarked by a line
averaging 200 pounds a man, rebounded last week with a 21-12
win over Allegheny College, after
losing to Westminster, 0-6, in the
se-ason's starter.

The four-man panel will be
composed of Dr. Sidney Painter,
Chairman of the History DepartMent; Dr. Clifford T. Morgan,
Chairman of the Psychology DePartment; Dr. Albert L. HamMond, Assistant Professor of Philosophy. A fourth speaker has not
Yet been announced.
The moderator for the discussion will be Professor Thomas
Engineering
Hubbard
of
the
School. The four members of the
discussion group were chosen as
representing the four basic viewPoints;
historic, psychological,
philosophical, and scientific; which
'Might be taken on the origin and
Place of religion. Each will have
an opportunity to give a brief
statement of his view, followed
by group discussion.

TBP Pledges
5 Seniors, 3 Juniors

Eight pledges have been accepted for membership in the Hopkins
Alpha Chapter of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity, this year.
The five seniors and three juniors tapped have only to complete
an essay on a topic of their choice
and carry out a few other duties
to become members.
The seniors and their respective
branches of engineering are: Donald C. Seyboth, Industrial; Chaplain W. Morrison, Mechanical;
Ronald E. Kaplan, Civil; Raymond
.T. Krizek, Civil;- and Casimir 111ilewski, Civil.
Recent Meetings
The juniors and their respective
branches are: William P. Anderson, Jr., chemical; Edmund T.
Urbanski, Electrical; and Jacob
J. Krauss, Mechanical.
TBP just recently had a meeting
of its eight members and, after
a short individual discussion with
each prospect, elected the above
mentioned eight. The names of
the prospects turned down and
the averages required for membership were not disclosed by the

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor
NEW PREXY'S EFFECT

This year two of the top colleges in the East, scholastic-wise,
have new men in their head office. Harvard University saw Dr.
Nathan Marsh Pusey (pronounced Pewzy) take over for Dr.
James B. Conant last Spring, while this past summer The Hopkins
pulled Dr. Lowell J. Reed out of retirement to become its seventh
president.
To administrators of intercollegiate athletics, the naming of
a new prexy of their university usually creates a feeling of
uneasiness. The same reaction is undoubtedly produced among all
people who must make adjustments to a new boss, but the men
in an athletic department now-a-days, feel it even more keenly
than other university employees for obvious reasons.
Last summer a New York Herald Tribune sports columnist
eame out with a statement that this Nester just couldn't forget.
The statement said, "Well-meaning presidents, with a disdain
for the physical and obsessive love for the intellectual, have been
known to go overboard for the object of their affections." This
put the reason for the downgrade of intercollegiate athletics in
many colleges all in one sentence.
DE-EMPHASIS TO COLLA.PSE

The columnist then referred the reader to the 1940 report
of the University of Chicago. For those who didn't know, Chicago
at one time was one of the top powers in intercollegiate athletics,
but today has weaker athletic teams than colleges even a fraction
its size in enrollment. Its basketball team plays a schedule of
"hick" colleges in the Illinois region and at present has the
longest losing streak in the history of collegiate basketball in the
IT. S. (to mention just one of its distinguished feats).
That is probably the worst that can happen to a university,
on the athletic fields when a new head man takes office. No wonder
athletic departments get the jitters when a new man steps in.
However, neither the coaches or directors of athletics at Harvard
and Hopkins have reason to get jitters. Both Dr.'s Pusey and
Reed see a prominent place of athletic activity in the building of
a young man into a well-rounded person.
Statements have come from both saying that their school's
athletic policy will stay as is during their stay in the head seat.
Both presidents were athletes of sorts in college. Hopkins' top
man played varsity tennis and even coached it after graduation
:while an instructor at Maine.
According to one of the recent issues of The Harvard Alumni
Bulletin: "While Mr: Pusey's undergraduate career was concentrated principally on scholarship ... he was a member of the
freshman basketball team and in his senior year (1928), he won
the great'Harvard-Yale-Brain Test', the one and only competition
of its kind ever held."

WHAT PRICE DE-EMPHASIS?

Yes, all three of these institutions of higher learning, Hopkins,
Harvard, and Chicago, are rated among the top in both undergrad and graduate scholastic circles. In the field of athletics it's a
different story. Harvard has definitely been on the down-grade in
recent years, while Chicago is in a hopeless situation (Chicago
big-wigs don't even go so far as to try and find time for their
students to have organized basketball practices).
As for The Hopkins, it, like Harvard, has definitely started
down. Dr. Reed says, he strongly supports the de-emphasis program as practiced here, however to numerous students at Homewood the big-men have gone overboard lately.
.

This Nester definitely feels as though there has been an overemphasis on the program initiated by G. Wilson Shaffer twenty
years ago. This overdoing has been highly noticeable in the three
years plus, at this institution. Prior to the turn of this second
half century the Jay teams were of a decided better quality.
What has caused this turn for the worse? Is it the fault of
the students or that of the administrators? Those are the
questions which this Nester plans on finding the answer to
before next June rolls around.

Jays' Frosh Grid Team
To Scrimmage Varsity
Although they have had extensive body contact work, the Jay
• freshman grid squad has done very
little scrimmaging thus far. Later
on in the year, the frosh will have
the Black and Blue Varsity as
scrimmage opponents.
Head Coach Marshall Turner
has been concentrating on fundamentals during the first weeks of
practice so that it will be unnecessary for him to repeat them after
the frosh season gets under way.
In the line, he is trying to choose
the best defensive men, figuring
that it is easier to learn to play
offense than to learn defense.
Thus far, Turner has been
working predominantly with two
backfield units. The first includes
Owen Fang, tailback, Bill Valentine, wingback, Chuck Soliz, fullback. and Jerry Carr, blocking
back.
The other unit has Jim Vallis
and-Dick Allen alternating in the
tailback slot, Tim Hughes, wingback, Harry Close, blocking back,
and Ed Mesko, fullback. Bob
Knerr is also a candidate for one
Of the backfield posts, according

to Turner.
Aiding the mentor with the
coaching chores are three students
besides Assistant Coach Jim Curtis, last year's varsity captain.
John O'Conner, a senior, and Jim
Dunne and Skip Smith; sophomores, are helping out gratis.
Both Smith and Dunne are transfer students, the former from the
Kings Point Maritime Academy,
and the latter from Michigan
State.

with smokers

The DSRC itself is engaged in
a new plan. It has elaborated
upon the gentleman's code by
writing a set of loose regulations
with which to govern the dormitory. Dave Jennings, DSRC president, hastened to say that this did
not mean that there would be
rules in the dormitory. "It merely
means," he said, "that the formerly 'hazy' idea of each man being
responsible to the others has been
written into a code in order that
the DSRC may more easily serve
the inhabitants of the dorm."

Again and again, over a full year and a half a group
of Chesterfield smokers have been given thorough
medical examinations... the doctor's reports are a
matter of record."No adverse effects to the nose,
throatand sinusesfrom smoking Chesterfields."
A responsible independent research laboratory supervises this continuing program.

"The individual has the free-

doni that he has always enjoyed
in the dorm here at Hopkins,"
Jennings said.
Both Phinney and Jennings were

in agreement that the dormitory
here at Hopkins should be indicative of life at the University and
that it should also be the center of
spirit and activity.

5 Seniors, 3 Juniors

Eight pledges have been accepted for membership in the Hopkins
Alpha Chapter of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity, this year.
The five seniors and three juniors tapped have only to complete
an essay on a topic of their choice
and carry out a few other duties
to become members.
The seniors and their respective
branches of engineering are: Donald C. Seyboth, Industrial; Chaplain W. Morrison, Mechanical;
Ronald E. Kaplan, Civil; Raymond
.T. Krizek, Civil;- and Casimir 111ilewski, Civil.
Recent Meetings
The juniors and their respective
branches are: William P. Anderson, Jr., chemical; Edmund T.
Urbanski, Electrical; and Jacob
J. Krauss, Mechanical.

of its eight members and, after
a short individual discussion with
each prospect, elected the above
mentioned eight. The names of
the prospects turned down and

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor
NEW PREXY'S EFFECT

This year two of the top colleges in the East, scholastic-wise,
have new men in their head office. Harvard University saw Dr.
Nathan Marsh Pusey (pronounced Pewzy) take over for Dr.
James B. Conant last Spring, while this past summer The Hopkins
pulled Dr. Lowell J. Reed out of retirement to become its seventh
president.
To administrators of intercollegiate athletics, the naming of
a new prexy of their university usually creates a feeling of
uneasiness. The same reaction is undoubtedly produced among all
people who must make adjustments to a new boss, but the men
in an athletic department now-a-days, feel it even more keenly
than other university employees for obvious reasons.
Last summer a New York Herald Tribune sports columnist
eame out with a statement that this Nester just couldn't forget.
The statement said, "Well-meaning presidents, with a disdain
for the physical and obsessive love for the intellectual, have been
known to go overboard for the object of their affections." This
put the reason for the downgrade of intercollegiate athletics in
many colleges all in one sentence.
DE-EMPHASIS TO COLLA.PSE

The columnist then referred the reader to the 1940 report
of the University of Chicago. For those who didn't know, Chicago
at one time was one of the top powers in intercollegiate athletics,
but today has weaker athletic teams than colleges even a fraction
its size in enrollment. Its basketball team plays a schedule of
"hick" colleges in the Illinois region and at present has the
longest losing streak in the history of collegiate basketball in the
IT. S. (to mention just one of its distinguished feats).
That is probably the worst that can happen to a university,
on the athletic fields when a new head man takes office. No wonder
athletic departments get the jitters when a new man steps in.
However, neither the coaches or directors of athletics at Harvard
and Hopkins have reason to get jitters. Both Dr.'s Pusey and
Reed see a prominent place of athletic activity in the building of
a young man into a well-rounded person.
Statements have come from both saying that their school's
athletic policy will stay as is during their stay in the head seat.
Both presidents were athletes of sorts in college. Hopkins' top
man played varsity tennis and even coached it after graduation
:while an instructor at Maine.
According to one of the recent issues of The Harvard Alumni
Bulletin: "While Mr: Pusey's undergraduate career was concentrated principally on scholarship ... he was a member of the
freshman basketball team and in his senior year (1928), he won
the great'Harvard-Yale-Brain Test', the one and only competition
of its kind ever held."

WHAT PRICE DE-EMPHASIS?

Yes, all three of these institutions of higher learning, Hopkins,
Harvard, and Chicago, are rated among the top in both undergrad and graduate scholastic circles. In the field of athletics it's a
different story. Harvard has definitely been on the down-grade in
recent years, while Chicago is in a hopeless situation (Chicago
big-wigs don't even go so far as to try and find time for their
students to have organized basketball practices).
As for The Hopkins, it, like Harvard, has definitely started
down. Dr. Reed says, he strongly supports the de-emphasis program as practiced here, however to numerous students at Homewood the big-men have gone overboard lately.
.

This Nester definitely feels as though there has been an overemphasis on the program initiated by G. Wilson Shaffer twenty
years ago. This overdoing has been highly noticeable in the three
years plus, at this institution. Prior to the turn of this second
half century the Jay teams were of a decided better quality.
What has caused this turn for the worse? Is it the fault of
the students or that of the administrators? Those are the
questions which this Nester plans on finding the answer to
before next June rolls around.
